thread.title: THIS is the date your £1 becomes worthless – and most people don't have a clue
thread.title_full: THIS is the date your £1 becomes worthless – and most people don't have a clue

title: THIS is the date your £1 becomes worthless – and most people don't have a clue
text:
GETTY WORTHLESS: The £1 coin will cease to be legal tender later this year 
The old round pound is set to be replaced from next month when the new safer 12-sided coin enters circulation. 
But despite the excitement around the new tender, new research shows a worrying number of Brits are set to lose out. 
Brits could lose £1.1billion in unspent £1 coins sitting in piggybanks, pockets and drawers if they don't cash them in before the cut off. Hidden treasure: could you be sitting on a FORTUNE? Tuesday, 10th January 2017 Amateur metal detectorists have been unearthing hoards of treasure on these shores for years. Could you be sitting on top of a fortune? 1 / 11 UIG via Getty Images This hoard of 126 rare Roman coins was found in Didcot in 1995 by an amateur metal detectorist. “We were shocked to discover just how few people are aware of when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation” Mark Barnett 
Nine out of 10 Brits are oblivious to the October 15 deadline when the old pounds will no longer be legal tender. 
The current £1 coin is being replaced for the first time in over 30 years amid fears it has become too vulnerable to counterfeiters. 
With approximately one in 30 £1 coins in circulation found to be a fake, the new coin is the safest design yet. 
On average, people have £15 in £1 coins sitting around at home, with young adults aged 18-24 hoarding the most –£25 typically, the study by Mastercard revealed. 
Mark Barnett, President of Mastercard UK and Ireland, said: "We were shocked to discover just how few people are aware of when the current £1 coin goes out of circulation." 
Some 2.2billion £1 coins have been struck by the Royal Mint since 1983 when it first came into circulation. 
Demand for the coin has soared recently with the new design set to come into force at the end of March. 
Collectors are racing to get their hands on all 24 designs of the round pound. Coins in your wallet WORTH a FORTUNE Friday, 6th January 2017 Are you sitting on a fortune? These coins and notes are worth up to £37,000! 1 / 9 EBAY "Cheerios" Dollar Sacagawea Coin: This 2000 Sacagawea "Cheerio" dollar regularly fetches $12,000 at auction. 
The most valuable £1 coin in circulation was revealed as the Edinburgh City quid which can fetch up to £50 online. 
But the Kew Gardens 50p — the most valuable of all British coins — is worth 240 x its face value at a cool £120. 
Brits across the country are checking their pockets in the hope of cashing in their rare treasure. 
Last week we revealed how to spot a rare £1 from your bog-standard pound. Related articles
